title: Monkey patch elasticsearch-env file so it parses on busybox.
body:
While elasticsearch [docs](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/starting-elasticsearch.html) do mention a requirement on bash, so far we haven't had issues running on busybox. https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/49612 unfortunately broke compatibility at the syntax level.

This might give motivation to install bash into our image if it continues, let's try once to hack around it and see how far it gets us. At the same time, I see some movement to support busybox in https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/52519 so it could work out fine in the end.

Fixes #3042

title: Apply prettier to zipkin-lens for automatic whitespace formatting.
body:
Note, this is just a strawman's proposal. Formatting preferences are not set-in-stone and I'm fine with just closing this PR if others don't like it. But figured it's worth giving one think on it.

I would say that automatic formatting using prettier is very common in the JS world, unlike say using Google Java Format for Java. As an example, our two most important dependencies, React and Material UI, both use it. So I think it can be said that it's idiomatic to use it - it's nice that's it's also "free" in terms of tooling, since it just integrates with our existing eslint. My personal opinion is not liking to think about formatting if a tool can do it for me, but interested in what others think on this.

title: Migrate lens build to create-react-app
body:
I originally was motivated to do this since the eslint command wasn't working on Windows and expected CRA to take care of it - but in the end it didn't include a lint command... But anyways, less configs to manage ourselves.

Some noticable differences from the previous code
- Typescript is enabled. We can start migrating files to typescript now, which we've wanted to do file a while. There's still a bit more work (mostly enabling lint for typescript) but I'll follow up in another PR for that
- No `devDependencies`. CRA seems to default to a style of only having a single dependencies block, which does make sense to me since this isn't a library, so there isn't really anything gained from separating dev and non-dev
- Zipkin logo switched from SVG to PNG. I noticed the SVG was just a base64-encoded PNG
- Import from `react-router-dom` instead of `react-router` since it reexports everything in `react-router`. I think this is more idiomatic than depending on both packages
- Some of the test data was javascript inside a JSON file. I think we had some workarounds in the jest config to deal with this but it's better to just migrate them to being proper javascript modules
- Similarly, JSON files need the `.json` extension when importing from tests, this is conventional and we had custom in our jest config to break from convention
- browserlist specified to reduce bundle size by reducing polyfills. Notably, IE, which is the primary need for most polyfills now adays, isn't supported. Not sure if this is a good idea I can re-include it if needed.

title: Add Archive Trace button
body:
This button lets you easily reupload the current trace to a different
server.

The main motivation for having this is that you can have the
archival server have a very long retention period and use it as very
long term storage for traces that you care about. For example when
sharing a trace in a jira ticket since otherwise the link would expire
after 1 week.

Design doc explaining the reason behind this in more details and why we
went with this implementation: https://github.com/openzipkin/openzipkin.github.io/wiki/Favorite-trace

title: Migrate from react-intl to linguijs.
body:
I originally used `react-intl` for localization since I've used it before and it's fairly common. However, when looking into migrating to `create-react-app`, I found `react-intl` doesn't work very well with it. While not a blocker, I looked around for alternatives and found LinguiJS, and I find it is better designed by providing very powerful macros. Also, initializing the i18n provider is far more intuitive (I didn't understand why I have to be the one to find out what messages to provide to react-intl...)

A comparison with `react-intl` - https://lingui.js.org/misc/react-intl.html

One thing I particularly like is `linguijs` supports patterns of using the source text itself as a message ID in addition to explicit IDs.

https://lingui.js.org/tutorials/react.html#message-id

As it says, the decision for one or the other is case-by-case. I think Zipkin is not YouTube, we don't have that many strings and the chance of having two strings with the same English but different translations (due to context differences) is very low that we don't have to worry about it. By using source language, our markup becomes easier to read (no importing in from a separate messages module) and more concise. 

Aside: it's quite fun being able to make this change without updating any test files!

title: Remove flexbox from top level app container to prevent flickering.
body:
I found this mostly by opening up inspector and randomly disabling CSS styles. But intuitively it does seem incorrect to apply flexbox and overflow: auto to the same element - both automatically reflow the content (flexbox by nature, overflow to compensate for a scroll bar) and probably are fighting each other in our flickeroo scenario.

From an encapsulation standpoint, it also seems fishy to have flexbox in the top level of the app since children can't rely lay themselves out correctly in such a case unless they are flexbox-aware themselves, hence encapsulation gets broken.

And when I remove this and open discover page, search for traces, go to trace, and open dependency page, I don't see any layout issues so it seems the flexbox isn't being used.

Fixes #2973

title: Remove unused scss definitions and convert renaming to normal css.
body: lens used to be an SCSS-styled app, but was migrated to Material UI and its JS styling solution. Now, we have a lot of unused variable definitions along with just a few external _css_ imports and a few lines of styles. We won't be adding any more styles here because we are using Material UI, so it makes sense to improve build performance a little by simplifying it. In particular, this removes the use of node-sass, a native extension which can cause some development headaches when the NodeJS version in pom.xml is different than that of the developer's machine.

title: Infer Zipkin base path based on current URL.
body:
Will add tests after getting an OK that the approach seems ok.

We previously passed a base path for zipkin through the server via a property. But I think it's relatively robust to just infer the base path from the browser URL. 

There is a difference regards to find traces URL - now they render at e.g., `/zipkin/?endTs...`, previously it was `/zipkin?endTs...` (note no trailing slash in that one). I remember we had an issue where we removed the trailing slash for this page, but I think with the unlaunch of classic (hence, no switching between the two UIs), this isn't an issue anymore, but I can't remember it well enough to be sure. Note that the server will redirect `/zipkin?endTs...` to `/zipkin/?endTs...` so both URLs will still be accepted.

Unblocks #2519

title: Read config.json in zipkin-lens and use it to set default query lookb…
body:
…ack.

- Fetches config.json before displaying the app
- Instead of initializing redux state when loading, initializes after fetching config with the config passed in so it can be tweaked based on configuration
- Switches lookback value from string like '15m' to milliseconds for more flexibility and uses `moment` to format duration instead of hardcoding
- Only overrides lookback from URL if there is actually a lookback in the URL
- I think fixes an issue with parsing lookback from URL, it was parsing out strings like '15m' though query parameter just has a number of milliseconds

I didn't get fancy and add a custom default lookback as an option in the menu, so if a user selects a lookback, the default would not be selectable again. If this seems important to make it selectable I can grunge it in.

Fixes #2969 
Unblocks #2491, #2519

title: Makes Lens default, removing the dependency on the classic UI
body:
For well over a year, we've been working on Lens, most notably @tacigar.

A year ago we added the ability to transition to the new Lens UI: a
"Try Lens" button which resulted in a lot of addressed feedback,
much of it personally done by @tacigar. Even before that, we asked
others to contribute and while some tasks have happened, not all.

We can't be in perpetual transition, and Lens is a very good UI. By
removing the classic one, ideally those really concerned about the
remaining features can help to implement them. Meanwhile, we allow
Zipkin to live longer by stopping the large and self-imposed burden
that displaces the small amount of time we have.

I don't think everyone will be happy about this, but that doesn't mean
continue to do nothing except add work on ourselves either. For this
reason I think we should proceed and remove classic on the next
release even if some folks don't like that.

cc @openzipkin/core @openzipkin/ui

repo.name: zipkin

title: Addressed Zipkin server crashing issue
body:
**Environment:** 
Platform: Pivotal Cloud Foundry
Memory: 1GB
Span Collector: RabbitMQ
Storage: MySQL

**Issue:**
Server crashes with resources exhausted error, when RabbitMQ queue has couple thousand messages.

**Cause:**
RabbitMQ broker delivers messages to consumer channel as soon as they are published to a queue. Since, Zipkin RabbitMQ collector utilizes auto acknowledgment feature, broker continuously deliver incoming messages through consumer channel, it doesn’t wait for an ack for a previously delivered message.

**Solution:**
Use channel prefetch count with manual acknowledgement to limit number of inflight/unacknowledged deliveries permitted on a consumer channel. Message consumption rate can be tuned through concurrency and synchronous span collection execution mode configurations.

title: Fix orphaned spans bug
body:
Fix an obvious bug pointed out in #2922 .

Mainly change the calculation method of `shownTree`.
Previously, **span ID** was used to calculate the span's parent-child relationship and Expand/Collapse buttons were implemented using that parent-child relationship.
This created the orphaned span problem pointed out in #2922 because orphaned spans don't have parent-child relationship using **span IDs**.

Please see here. Orphan spans are simply appended to the root span:
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/8a5609a44ea52fa85d5309d7e4e46bc70a4c3ca8/zipkin-lens/src/zipkin/span-node.js#L272-L276

This PR uses span indices to calculate parent-child relationship instead of span IDs.

p.s. TraceSummary component is fairly complex, so I wanted to create custom hooks and improve readability, but I'm not doing it now to minimize PR.

### Before

![before-orphaned](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19551419/71953945-0bb8df80-3227-11ea-84f0-5abbb9fb3a83.gif)

### After

![after-orphaned](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19551419/71954327-5129dc80-3228-11ea-99bd-dc64a919b3b9.gif)

title: Use dependency management to manage Jackson version.
body:
It's easy for Jackson artifacts to get misaligned due to its multiple artifacts and our may transitive dependency paths. We've already had to manually manage it once to fix a security issue and now it's happening again. Let's go ahead and manage the Jackson version permanently since we use it directly now anyways after the moshi migration, and it's API tends to be fairly stable.

Fixes #2941

title: Show client's remote service name in all cases. Fixes #2932
body:
The code had a check to only show the client's remote service name when the span doesn't have any children.

Problem is described in https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/2932

Basically, when reactive HTTP client (Java in my case) is used, CLIENT spans are created in hierarchical order.

Use case:

```
Incoming request:
Two parallel operations:
1. Fetch user A, update user A
2. Fetch user B, update user B
Wait for completion...
```
Is producing CLIENT spans in hierarchical order:
```
-> Main span 
  -> "Fetch user A" CLIENT span -> `update user A` CLIENT span
  -> "Fetch user B" CLIENT span -> `update user B` CLIENT span
```
But UI doesn't support it.

title: Use react-fontawesome instead of using fontawesome directly
body:
Before, Zipkin Lens used Font-Awesome directly, but I think this way has the following problems.

* Additional configs are required for Webpack (see: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/08cee5023bf6e24c277bce85839ad1c043230f63/zipkin-lens/webpack.dev.config.js#L51-L54)
* All icons need to be imported, so bundle size will increase (see: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/08cee5023bf6e24c277bce85839ad1c043230f63/zipkin-lens/scss/main.scss#L19-L22)

I think it is better to use Font-Awesome through React components provided by Fort-Awesome (https://github.com/FortAwesome/react-fontawesome).
This library seems to avoid such problems.

title: Only collect metrics for API endpoints.
body:
Currently we attach metric collection to the entire server, with a currently insufficient blacklist that allows static resources to be recorded. Instead, we should just go ahead and whitelist to the API endpoints as that's what really matters for metrics and are in our grafana.

Fixes #2928

title: Use Jackson to write names and write to pooled buffer to reduce garbage.
body:
We have an optimization to write out names as a quoted list for names, but this doesn't really work due to JSON's escaping rules. So instead we should stick to using Jackson which escapes correctly. We can get some performance back in exchange though by writing into a pooled buffer to reduce garbage generation.

Fixes #2915

title: Armeria Server Configurator to Consumer Server Builder
body:
Replacing Armeria Server configurator with ServerBuilder consumer to add services.

@anuraaga this PR is to showcase that replacing configurator with consumers is not working out-of-the-box. I did this to check that is not something related to [1], and might be related with how Zipkin server is configured. 

[1] https://github.com/openzipkin-contrib/zipkin-storage-kafka/issues/61

Anyhow, I'm fine keeping configurator in both Zipkin and Kafka Storage if it's required; and we can close this if you agree.

title: Add query timeout knob.
body:
Currently, there is a hard server timeout of 11s. For queries, requests can be very long, especially when using Elasticsearch. While we can configure the Elasticsearch client timeout, we also need to make sure the query APIs themselves don't timeout.

Fixes #2809

title: Loading indicators to discover page
body:
## Summary

If users store a large amount of data, the data fetch time will be longer.
In this case, if the loading indicator is not displayed, the user may simply think that there is no data on zipkin-server.
This is a very big UX issue. we should fix it as soon as possible.

## Screenshots

![loading-services](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19551419/67825845-ff6d2380-fb0d-11e9-9c6a-b2c49b8a1967.gif)

![loading-traces](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19551419/67825853-05fb9b00-fb0e-11e9-812e-3645394eb071.gif)

title: Switches to use exact same OSGi profile as brave
body:
Eventhough we have only one module using OSGi (zipkin), it is better to
use the exact same config as brave, as this makes cross-project work
easier to reason with.

See https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/pull/1013

title: Update mockwebserver
body:
## Changelog
- Move `okhttp.version` to `zipkin-parent` so that all remaining usages of `okhttp3` (mostly on tests) follow the same version.
- Update `mockwebserver` on `zipkin-junit` to `v4.2.2` (same as `zipkin-server`).

## Context
`zipkin-junit` currently points to `com.squareup.okhttp3:mockwebserver` `v3.14.4`. This makes it tricky to update `okhttp3` on packages which use `zipkin-junit`. 

Since `zipkin` is moving away from `okhttp` to `armeria`, a cleaner solution would probably be to remove completely `okhttp` from `zipkin-junit` and `zipkin-server`, but that seems a far larger change.

While I was there, I also thought it would make sense to ensure that all the remaining usages of `okhttp3` follow the same versions. That's why I moved the dependencies to the `dependencyManagement` section of the `zipkin-parent`'s `pom.xml`.

title: Tweak the build and reduce lodash import.
body:
Figured it'd be nice to add some features to minimize JS build size and keep it in check. In practice, the bundle is only affected ~10K since the main culprit of lens size is fontawesome, which we can improve by migrating to `react-fontawesome` or material-ui icons so we only bundle what we use - @tacigar do you happen to have any plan on migrating icons?

- Clean `target/classes` before compiling. Otherwise JS builds up in there which all get packed into the JAR - not an issue in our production builds since they start clean but makes debugging bundle size harder locally
- We're currently targeting a fixed version of modern browsers that gets older over time, but we may as well target the most recent ones automatically
- Enable `@babel/plugin-transform-runtime` to optimize code generation of polyfills. The impact isn't so large though since we only target modern browsers
- Have webpack dump an HTML with its stats to `target/stats.html` to be able to see how the ES6 module size is doing
- Replace lodash full import with method imports. Before, all of lodash was being loaded but now only the used methods are

Biggest dependency is visceral, followed by moment since we load but don't use all locales, and then chart.js

- while there is a moment webpack plugin to not load locales, it's probably better to just migrate to day.js
- I could only find one usage of chartjs, for a `Doughnot` on the dependencies page. Wonder if there's a more optimized way of rendering that

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/198344/67562542-dc332480-f759-11e9-9e52-d372991002b3.png)

title: Redesign dependencies page
body: ## Summary Mainly I do the following two things in this PR. * Detach Dependencies from DiscoverPage. * Refactor Dependencies code. ## Details ### Detach Dependencies from DiscoverPage Dependencies are currently embedded in the Discover Page as follows: At first glance, this design seems to share GlobalSearch between traces searching and dependencies searching. Actually, however, Dependencies search uses only Lookback search criteria. I thought this would be very confusing to users. And, I think that the topology view considered here(https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/2701) should be placed where Dependencies is now. Therefore I want to detach dependencies from DiscoverPage. ### Refactor Dependencies code Currently, the code of Dependencies is the oldest and worst code in Lens. I want to refactor it. ## Screenshots

title: Bump span name and autocomplete limit to 10k
body:
The main monolith at Yelp has more than 1k span names. This is due to
several reasons, main one being that all mysql queries also have
"yelp-main" as localEndpoint.serviceName. Since we use the query
fingerprint as name, this causes us to have around 6k span names.

title: Enable license plugin on Travis.
body:
License plugin is currently disabled on Travis. I guess this makes the plugin somewhat pointless as we've seen routinely checking in files without license.

The issue referenced that showed issues with Travis's shallow clone is quite old, and since it seems to work fine on Docker Hub, which also does a shallow clone, let's give it a try and see if this passes the build - if so it means the problem might not be there anymore.

Fixes #1512
